At this point, it still looks more like deflation. While one sector of our local market is beginning to sag (starter homes at $250k will do that), others are showing expansion with properties actually reducing time on the market. 
 
 I'm not a member of any real estate association and unable to get national numbers on sales/default trends, so my comments are confined to our local market. A local guy keeps me updated on our surrounding area and we still aren't seeing any abnormal defaults, with the rental market remaining underutilized and under priced. About 20% of the rental market is estimated to be investors with negative cash flow waiting for capital gain status on appreciation, so they'll take the first hit.
 
 The major market here is $3-450k and buyers are primarily out of state retirees, so we won't have negative impact in that sector until resales in other states decline to a point of alarm. Oddly enough, a majority of the retirees have sold their homes up to two years ago and spent time traveling before deciding on a permanent retirement location. 
 
 Our younger people were forced out of the market by appreciation two-years ago ($16/hr is a good job here). Rents remain low enough that manufactured housing can't compete for that business.
 
 The middle market of $5-800k is still very strong, again retirees. Above that is custom home territory here and rural land prices here are still far below any favored major metropolitan area. As long as what would be a $2mm+ home with privacy elsewhere can be built here for $1mm, in many instances a second home, the general economy or real estate markets won't affect that sector as those buyers aren't dependent on loan qualification ratios or equity market performance.

 There's the problem. Banks and other mortgage lenders prefer operating as commission brokers. They cherry-pick what they refer to as to non-qualifiers (50% equity to the loan) for their own portfolios and send the rest off in packages by risk factor to one of the huge, quasi-government outfits to be bundled and sold as securities. If Ginnie Mae is sitting with a portfolio of say $400k homes financed for 90%, $360k,values drop even 20% and their portfolio book value is underwater by 10%. If they can still service the debt, nobody gets worried. If loans turn non-performing, no payments, default begins and the $360k house might be sold for say $200k, leaving $160k of bonds that have to be redeemed due to no cash flow to service the debt.
